[GRAMMAR]: Occasional awkward sentence structures (e.g., "I had fancied him reading it with relish, but if Corvick wasn’t satisfied how could Vereker himself be?")
[LEXICON]: Some outdated or less common vocabulary may hinder smooth reading for modern readers (e.g., "lucubrations", "ormolu")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition between the end of Chapter I and the beginning of Chapter II without clear connection
[CLARITY]: Some sentences are overly complex or convoluted, potentially confusing the reader (e.g., "The impression he made on me personally was such that I wished him to read it, and I corrected to this end with a surreptitious hand what might be wanting in the careless conspicuity of the sheet.")

[GRAMMAR]: Occasional awkward phrasing (e.g., "the liberty had been taken wjth myself" in context, though not in the evaluated segment, sets a tone; in the segment: "I had had on my tongue’s end" feels slightly archaic or awkward in this context)
[LEXICON]: Archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "unmodulated", while correct, may cause a slight pause for some readers)

[STRUCTURE]: Sudden shift in scene (from the fireplace to dinner) without clear transitional phrases
[CLARITY]: Vereker's character reaction ("Oh, it’s all right—the usual twaddle!") could be more clearly motivated or set up for maximum impact
[TRANSITION]: The connection between Lady Jane's pleasure and the dinner scene could be smoother
